alert.note: Alert for Pierce (Washington) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Flood Warning issued February 28 at 12:05PM PST until March 01 at 1:54PM PST by NWS Seattle
info.description: ...The National Weather Service in Seattle WA has issued a Flood Warning for the following rivers in Washington... Puyallup River Near Orting affecting Pierce County. Nisqually River Near National affecting Lewis and Pierce Counties. Cowlitz River At Randle affecting Lewis County. .A strong storm is coming in to western Washington with multiple factors that will produce high runoff and flooding. Heavy, prolonged rainfall will be coupled with some snow snow melt in low to mid elevations of the mountains from rising snow levels and strong warm and moist winds. This will drive some rivers above minor to major flooding. ...FLOOD WARNING IN EFFECT FROM THIS EVENING TO EARLY TOMORROW AFTERNOON... * WHAT...Minor flooding is forecast. * WHERE...Puyallup River Near Orting. * WHEN...From this evening to early tomorrow afternoon. * IMPACTS...At 10000.0 cfs, the Puyallup river will flood low lying areas near Orting and along the upper reaches, including along Orville Road East south of Brooks Road, Neadham Road, and the vicinity of the County Subdivision/Tomolla Farm. High flows will also increase the threat of channel migration and bank erosion. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 11:15 AM PST Monday the flow was 4720.0 cfs. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise above flood stage this evening to a crest of 12630 cfs late this evening. It will then fall below flood stage late tonight. - Flood flow is 10000.0 cfs. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 12200.0 cfs on 01/29/1965. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood &&
info.instruction: Caution is urged when walking near riverbanks. Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Flooding is occurring or is imminent. Most flood related deaths occur in automobiles. Do not attempt to cross water covered bridges, dips, or low water crossings. Never try to cross a flowing stream, even a small one, on foot. To escape rising water find another route over higher ground. Additional information is available at www.weather.gov. The next statement will be issued by this evening at 800 PM PST.
